contextId.information: Both statements mean basically same thing. The word "house" is a metonym that represents the descendants of Israel. But, both "people" and "house" probably are a synecdoche representing the soldiers of Israel. AT: "for the Israelite soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: for the people of Yahweh, and for the house of Israel

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated as part of the poetry of the song. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Do not tell it in Gath ... do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon

contextId.information: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh had chosen David to be king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will become ruler over Israel

contextId.information: These two phrases have similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. They both are polite ways to refer to death and dying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: When your days are fulfilled and you lie down with your fathers

contextId.information: The phrase "she came in to him" is a graphic description of David having sex with the woman. These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that they slept together. AT: "he slept with her" or "he had sex with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: she came in to him, and he slept with her

contextId.information: The phrase "went in to her" is a graphic description of David having sex with his wife. These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that they slept together. AT: "slept with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: went in to her, and slept with her

contextId.information: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Sheba is emphasizing that he and the tribes of Israel have no relationship with David. AT: "The inheritance of David and his father's family does not belong to us" or "We are not a part of David and his father's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]]))
contextId.quote: We have no part in David, neither have we any inheritance in the son of Jesse

contextId.information: These two sentences have similar meanings. AT: "What can I do to remove this sin, so that you may bless the people of Yahweh, who inherit his goodness and promises?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: What should I do for you? How can I make atonement ... promises?

contextId.information: These phrases mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. AT: "I have sinned terribly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I have sinned, and I have acted perversely
